document.text: TI1UR8DAY. R. D. Forbes testified  1 live half le from J. S. Forbesnot in sight. n morning of the 4th of March my ncle came over after me. I then ent Floyd Jones after Cliff I then ent to the fire with uncle and began i save the things looked in trunk old him to get out papers and brimr ver to my house he said he had mie money in tray of trunk he also ad some in bottom of trunk in hi coat pocket, which was rumpled up. He said, I am robbed money was one out of hs pocket no money as found in trunk colored boy. anie, and Aunt Nancy were there made a thorough search for the tracks and other evidence found tracks leading into plowed land tracks showed one person tracks bowed he stooped to fire smoke house measured the trackheres he stickI measureu several tracks ind they were the same. Woolridge id, Suppose we compromise this thing and throw out those smoke ruse tracks and have the other wo there were track- of two other pereons. Here a pair of heavy coaree bro- gan shoes were exhibited and the measure was applied and tested and fitted. The shoes were identified as those of Woolridges. On cross-examination witness ad mitted that Woolridge struck a trail which cirried him up to Dora Gulps after he came back from Appomat tox. We all went up there and measured an iron-sunk heel, about an 11 or 12 shoe l was satisfied there was nothing iu it. It is said you were charged with the burning? 1 have never been accused of this burning, except Cliff accused me of this buruiug, and I would like to in troduce witnesses to show that Cliff charged me with this burning. 1 would like to insist that the witness es b put on the stand to prove this fret. Some years ago there was bit terness between Woolridge and I. Superintendent J. K. Hannah, of Appomattox, said -he dined with E. C. Woolridge and his uaughter at ppomattox. He said Woolridge told him that all the buildings of J. S. Forbes were burned this was the first I had heard of the fire. J. F. Dickerson, an Appomattox School Trustee, testified that Wool ridge told him he wrote the will of the late Mr. Forbes, and when told that he Dickerson bad heard that Charlie Forbes was implicated, Woolridge replied that it v,as not so that Janie had written Charlie and he would be here in a few days. E. C. Spencer testifies  I heard that Charlie Forbes had been mur dered on the 21st March nothing had been done to,find him a party of Forbes, Morgan and myself went up to look for him Mr. B. T. Morgan said Charlie had come back I tried to find him and could not, went to Woolridges farm asked him out. Well, Cliff, wheres Charlie ? Who, Charlie Forbes? I dont know! He didnt have anything to do with the fire I wish I could find him. Ive got a letter I want to show you. He was go nervous he couldnt rend .t. He showed guilt as plain as an man he 3pencer ever saw. Well, Cliff, we have always been friends, and I have an Minpleasant duty to perform. Ill have to take you. All right. Ive been expecting it. Ill go with you. He asked lor time to pnt on his clothes we went iu with him he aBked I suppose you all have a warrant for me ? Cliff, you know me well enough tha I wouldnt come after you with out a warrant. Mrs. Woolridge said, JVhile the buildings were burning my littl boy was erving for Cliff to scratch his back that Charlie Forbes was there that morning he paid his father 9 for guano in the morning and came back that night and got it. We started out Wooldrige told only one of the children good bye told his wife to tell Hal Flood and Sam Ferguson to come on down. Where are you going to carry me ? We talked about Farmville an decided to go there Woolridge said he first heard of the fire the nex morning, and asked why didnt the foolish girl ring the bell. Why didnt you go over there and send your sou to Appomattox ?, 11 said he had a young horse to work denied that he had been writing to Charlie under an assumed name said his postofiice was Wert, a few days ago he had it changed to Forbes said that he had not received nidi from any other office. I have said that I would help lynch the parties who did the burn ing, out had no idea I would ever be caught. I am fifty-seven years old and this disgrace is tough. At Forbes postoffice we fe d. Did yopt say Charlie was withiu four and a-half miles of this place Woolridge answered, Echo an swers where?  Tell me and I will catch him ! This is not the time, he said I will tell Ira Orange where he can catch him At Wilburns bridge he called for paper and peucil and wrote Phone Winston McKiuney to see Joe Harvey at Rose Bower and find out positively about Charlie Forbes, and go on by Goins and Jones old place. Woolridge said in a deep study  Well, there were three of us you have me get the others.

After the medals were awarded all of the contestants were addressed by Hon. H. D. Flood. Then the entire school was ad dressed by Dr. Taylor. I 11 addition to the-, above men tioned speakers. Superintendent J. K. Hannah, and Trustee J. F. Dickerson were on the stand, who made brief speeches endorsing and praisipg the progress made in the school. They expressed themselves g8 being highly satisfied .with the work aud to all appearances they were as full of the commeucement as one o fjh e ndalista.  Mrs. J. R. Atwood presided at the organ, and direcred the music dur ing the exercises. The Concord String Baud, composed of Mess4. S. Hoffman Fisher, William Steele and Haunah Evans, entertained the audience with sweet music from popular selections. PICIMARY DEPARTMENT,

document.text: sister Southern States, which had already seceded. The call went out for volunteers to defend the firesides of the Old Do minion. Appomattox County responded nobly. A Cavalry Company was formed under the command of Capt. Joel W. Flood, becoming Co. H of the 2nd Va. Cavalry. A Company of Heavy Artillery was formed under Capt. James Robertson. A Company of Infantry under Capt. Thos. P. Mat thews, and another Company was formed under Capt. Wm. H. Abbitt, and quite a number of Appomattox citizens living near the rim of the county joined companies from adjoining coun ties. With hearts aflame and bodies dedicated to the Cause they held dear, they went to the front and shared the destiny of the heroes in Gray. Weakened by casualties, new calls came for volunteers, and long after the war, there was a scarcity of able bodied men in the County. Then came April 9, 1865, and the hand of destiny wrote finis across the scroll of four mighty years of struggle Destiny selected Appomattox for one of the major events oi history. Today there is hardly a town- or village in America, that has not heard of Appomattox. Thus ended in this Coun ty, one of the greatest Civil Wars ever chronicled in the files of Time, and at Appomattox began a new page in the history of America. Military rule was established shortly after April 9, 1865. Al county officers were replaced by military appointees. These were men who were selected upon the recommendation of the incumbents, and were willing to take the Iron Clad Oath. In the fall of 1866, an election was held under the Under wood Constitution, which put into effect the 13th and 14th Amendments to the Constitution of the United States, and a new slate of officers were named. Geo. T. Peers became Clerk Wm. T. Johnson Sheriff W. J. Collins, Commissioner of the Revenue the Office of County Treasurer was created Supervisors were provided for, and the ounty Government, practically as we have it now was estab lished. The ravages of four years of war were apparent, and Ap pomattox along with her sister counties, began to repair the wounds. The following years called forth the character and ability of her people, and the present institutions of our Coun- -y are but a tribute to their untiring labor and foresight. From 1870 to the present has been a period of rebuilding and achievement. From its creation the County has been served until now by the following Officers CIRCUIT JUDGESJudges G. A. Wingfield, J. D. Hors- rv, Sam Coleman, George J. Hundley, Robt. F. Hutcheson and Joel W. Flood. COUNTY JUDGESLewis Daniel Isbell, Henry T. Par-  rish and David A. Christian. TRIAL JUSTICEST. R. Horseley and L. F. Ferguson. COUNTY CLERKSJohn T. Bocock, Henry F. Bocock, Geo. T. Peers, Geo. W. Abbitt, John Rolfe Horsley and Claude W. Smith. , COMMONWEALTHS ATTORNEYSThos. S. Bocock, L. D. Isbell, Crawford Jones, Edward Woodson, T. J. Thornhill, David A. Christian, W. C. Franklin, H. D. Flood, Samuel L. Ferguson, Joel W. Flood and W. M. Abbitt. SHERIFFSJoel Watkins, Geo. T. Peers, William Paris, Wilson Hix, W. T. Johnson, Wm. H. Gills, Cooch Plunkett, T. B. Bryant, S. P. Coleman, Frank W. McKinney and H. W. Mc Kinney. COMMISSIONERS OF THE REVENUEThos W. Johns, Isaac Adams, Andrew B. Baker, John W. Gilliam, Geo. W. Ab bitt, Van Gilliam, Wm. Statham, L. E. Smith, H. C. Babcock, E. R. Abbott and J. H. OBrien. COUNTY TREASURERSWm. H. Gills, Cooch Plunkett, S. R. Franklin, D. Mott Robertson, R. F. Burke and R. L. Burke. SUPERINTENDENTS OF SCHOOLSC. H. Chilton, J. B. Bristow, J. K. Hannah, N. R. Featherston and J. A. Burke. HOUSE OF DELEGATESThe following citizens of the county have served in the House of Delegates Col, Samuel D. McDearmon, Zachariah Cheatham, Crawford Jones, R. P. Poore, Joel W. Flood, Thos. S. Bocock, James Watkins, D. Mott Robertson, W. C. Franklin, H. D. Flood, J. W. Harwood, Ster ling C. Stratton, Willis H. Ligon, J. R. Horsley, J. C. Jones, A. B. Thornhill, T. J. Stratton, J. W. Cawthorn and R. L. Burke. The Constitution of 1902, abolished the County Court, the duties of which were transferred to the Circuit Court, the County Clerk and the Board of Supervisors.

document.text: Royall, a progressive Baptist minister, on behalf of self and others presented a petition for the establishment of a high school at Appomattox Depot. This matter was referred to a committee made up of clerks of the three districts. A year later after the committee reported that no aid could be obtained from citizens of the village, the committee was discharged. Mr. J. K. Hannah, .a member of the school and later superintendent of schools in 1894, moved that the funds wMch were ordered by the Board of Supervisors be used in the establishment of a graded school either at the Old j Court House or Ap.omattox De-

document.text: Richmond Va., Oct. 16.1899. Supt, J. K. Hannah, Pamplin City, Va., D eab S ib  Replying to your letter just received I have to say that I think it prudent for yon to suspend yonr visits to the schools for the present unless your district trustees think otherwise. The vac cination law should be rigorously enforced in every county and city of the State aud enforced at once. If the pareiiU of the children will uot, or cannot have them vaccinated, the proper authorities should liavV it done. The State Board of Health fears a smallpox scourge this winter unless every precaution is taken to prevent it. I am very truly yours, J oseph W. S outhall , Supt. Public Instruction.

document.text: P am plin City B udget. Misses Annie and Irene Marshall left for their schools in North Caro lina on the evening of the 8th instf Misses Bristow, of Hixburg, took the train here on Friday en route for the Worlds Fair. Mr. Eugene Locke, of Crewe, has been visiting his friends and college- mates, Mr. J. H. Franklin, of this place, and Mr. Leslie N. Liggon, of Hixburg, for the past week. Mr. Pusley M. Hannah came down on Saturday with a load of forty watermelons which averaged forty pounds. Mrs. E. B. Brady made a short visit to Prospect last week. Mr. N. A. Davis, operator at Roan oke, was in town on Sunday last. Dr. And Mrs. E. H. Grigg left on yesterday for Buckingham,where they will spend a few days visiting rela tives and friends. Miss Lizzie Pankey returned on the west bound train yesterday from Spout Springs, where she has been visiting the family of Dr. D. Mott Robertson. Mr. Christopher Atkinson passed through town this morning en route for his cousins, Mr. J. K. Hannah. Mr. A. is just returning from a trip to the Worlds Fair. Miss Sallie E. Rice returned a few days ago from a visit to her friends, Dr. and Mrs. Robert M. Davis, of Evergreen. Mr. Marshall Morton leaves to day for Hampden Sidney College where he matriculates for the ses sion. Mrs. Anderson M. Jennings, one of the oldest ladies of our town, died this morning in the 75th year of her age. She leaves a husband aud five children to mourn her loss. Mrs. S. E. J. Walker, of Peters burg, is in town with the view of purchasing a store-house and lot of Mr. John R. Franklin. P. H. E. Sept. 12, 1893.

document.text: istees are the term of office of one class expiring on the 7th of each November, as follows The first class was composed of Messrs. T. J. Stratton, T. A. Smith and J. K. Hannah, whose e m ex pires on the 7th of Nov. 1897. The second class was composed of Messrs. E. L. Anderson, J. F. Dickerson and J. T. Moses, whose term expired Nov. 7tli, 189G. The third class was composed of Messrs. E. A. Walton, J, W. Gilliam and L. A. Williams, whose term expired on the 7th of Nov. 1895, but as Iheir successors were not appointed in 95 they held over under the law until the lecent appointments. Last November the school electoral . board of this county elected six trustees. There were several changes made in the personnel of the board. This has given rise to dissatisfaction on the part of some of those who were not re-elected we understand, and of criticism by some adverse to the ac tion of the school board. This appears to us as being strange, as these positions have gener ally been regarded as burdensome and little sought after. But sup pose they are places of honor and emolumentdid not this same elec toral board elect these gentlemen when they were last elected P Then if the offices have not been burden some do these gentlemen not owe the board some measure of gratitude for the votes that elevated them to these honora ile posi ions ? Itisb u t right that these positions should change hands occasionally. A mail is elected for three years and not for life. When his three years is out, if he is not re-elected it does not imply bad treatment. In all of our educational institutions the vis itors and trustees are constantly be ing changed. O je of these gentlemen we under stand is getting up certificates of good character. His character has not been attacked or impugned as far as we have been able to learn, not a member of the board has said a word derogatory of one of the ex- trustees. We have to say that when public officers perform their official duties, the public will acqueise in the re sult, unless,tbei e is some very good reason for contrary action. There is certainly no good reason why D. M. Anderson, A. G. Owen, A. H. Howerton and W. P. Gills should not be put in any position of respon sibility. It may be interesting for the public to know that of the new trustees, Messrs. D. M. Anderson, Owen and Howerton were elected in i place of Messrs. E. L. Anderson, A. E. Walton and J. T. Moses without a dissenting vote on the board and all three members were present.

document.text: from public taxes. In 1870, this in novation met with considerable op position. Good judgment finally prevaield and the County Public School System was begun on a very modest scale. The first public school in this county was located in a log cabin near the Old Court House. The first teacher in the public school system was J. H. Featherston. The first County Superintendent of Schools was C. H. Chilton, 1870- 1881. He was succeeded by J. B. Bristow, who continued in office un til 1885. Mr. Chilton returned to office in that year and served until 1897. Sucessors in office were J. K. Hannah, 1897-1913 N. R. Feather ston, 1913-1926 and J. A. Burke, 1926 to date, The first public school house built with county funds was erected at Hurtsville. Other school structures were added as fast as funds from school taxes made these accomoda tions possible. Mr. N. R. Featherston, in his his tory of Appomattox County, re ports that the school term in the early days of the system was five months. Teachers average monthly salary was 25.00. In 1908, Professor Lindsay Craw ley was apointed principal of the high school at Appomattox. The frame building housing the high school stood on the lot where the present T. W. Moses residence is located. There were three teachers and 160. students. Funds allocated by the legislature in this year, with matching donations by private citi zens, financed the building of a new high school at the present site. Appomattox High School open ed in September, 1909, with the im posing name of Tenth Congression al District High School. Our public school system has made great advances in the years since 1909. In the past ten years alone, we have seen the construc tion of a new and up-to-date agri cultural vocational building at the high school addition of a hew gym nasium construction of the Carver- Price High School and elementary school for Negroes, and the build ing of the new elementary school in the town of Appomattox. For the current session, total enrollment in county public schools is 2,300 pupils, with 93 teachers.

document.text: F bom S chool S uperintendent . Pam pi in City, Va., Oct. 10th 1899. To the P ublic  The contagions disease that has been existing in the lower end of Appomattox Co. for several weeks was pronounced on Wednesday, the 18th, by Dr. C. S. Morton, of Pamplin, and Dr. Win- stou, an expert, from Farmville. to be genuine smallpox. By the ad vice of these two physicians I have ordered all the schools in this end of the county to be suspended for the present. There are six or eight cases in a tenants family on my own plantation. There has been a 3 a rict quarantine observed between this tenauts family and my own. For fear some aught think I was neglecting my school duties, I will publish a letter from the State Superintendent in answer to one 1 wrote in regard to this disease. The proper authorises should take hold of these cases at once ami toil the disease. Resp. J. K. HANNAH, Supt. Public Schools.

document.text: Democrats of Appomattox Hold an Enthusiastic Mass-Meeting. A large and enthusiastic mass- meeting of the Democrats of Appo mattox was held at the Court House n Courtday to elect delegates to the Staunton convention. The meeting was called to order by Mr. Joseph Button, county chairman. Mr. W. II. Ligon, was elected chairman, and Mr. S. L. Ferguson, secretary of the meecing. The following delegates and alter nates were elected Delegates at large ton, It. B. Poore, H. D. Mott Robertson. Alternates at large ton, J. R. Atwood, T. J. and J. K. Hannah. Southside districtDelegates . John Overton, J. C. Jones. R. F. Burke and W. II. Lewis. Alter nates, S. P. Coleman, A. H. Abbitt, C. N. Abbitt and G. A. Walton Stonewall districtDelegates  I. M. Golliday, S. C. Stratton, Walter Forbes, and D. A. Christian. A1 ternates J. R. Horsley, J. W. Davidson, E. A. Walton and M. F. Kyle. Clover Hill districtDelegates  W. H. Ligon, W. B. Forbes, E. E, Chism, and S. L. Ferguson. Alter nates  R. W. Bristow, L. A. Bagby, W. J. Trent and F. W. McKinney. The following resolutions were introduced by Senator H. D. Flood and adopted with but one dissenting voice. Resolved, by the Democratic party of Appomattox county,in mass meet ing assembled First. That we reiterate and re affirm our allegiance to the Demo cratic party, and pledge our heatty support to the nominees of the Dem ocratic convention, national and dis trict. Second. That we favor the free and unlimited coinage of silver at the ratio of 10 to 1 , without reference to the position of any other nation on this questin, and hereby instruct our delegates to thcState convention not to vote for any oue as a delegate to the national convention who does not favor this policy.

document.text: Circuit Court. Judge Hundley opened his court here on Alonday afternoon. Alany chancery papers were put into his hands, and several orders entered. The first cases reached ou the law docket were those against C. H. Chilton. Therewere six of them. They are damage suits .under the statut 8 for uttering and publishing defamatory and insulting words. Three of these suits were tried on yesterday, namely, those brought by D. Alott Robertiou, J. H. Robertson, aud J. K. Hannah. In the first of these there was a verdict for 1000, anl in each of the other two for 800. Upon the calling of the first case, that of D. Mott Robertsou, ou Mon day afternoon, Mr. W. G. Franklin entered au appearauce as Counsel for Mr. Chilton, and after entering a plea of not guilty, moved for a change of venue, aud.iu support of his motion offered the affidavit of his client setting forth that there could not he a jury empanelled in Appomattox county that would do him justice that officials of the county were among the plaintiffs, aud their influence would override the cause of justice and that he could not come for fear of bodily harm. The court promptly over ruled the motion for a change of venue but granted the motion for a special jury. Ou Tuesday morning the Robert sou case was taken up, with the fol lowiug special jury J. F. Dicker- son, G. E. Lewis, Milton Isbell, J. E. Chick, W. F. Wright, T. J. Good ing, C. E. Carson, J. N. Turner, T. E. Owen, R. T. Phelps, J. C. Shear er and C. R. Alann. Mr. Franklin made no further appearance in this caee, nor in the two others that were tried. There are three other cases on .he docket against Mr. Chilton of similar char acter, but it is thought that these will probably not be tried at the preseut term. ibe suit of Caskie  Coleman aud Sackett  Jackett agaiust Thomas Harvey to recover fees re sulted iu a verdict tor plaintiffs for 75. The suit of Deaveuports adminis trator agaiust the Norfolk  Wes tern Railroad is set for to-morrow and will probably be tried. The action is brought for damages for the killing of the plaintiffs sou at this depot last year through alleged negligence on part of the defendant.

document.text: at Buchanan on the 16th day of August, 1894, be hereby instruct ed to use all honorable and proper means at their hands to secure him as our nominee, and to stand by him so long as his name is before the convention. Col. R, B. Poore, at this point, delivered an address to the people, urging upon them the desirability of sending to Congress a man from the epstern section of the district. The next thing in order was the election of two delegates at large. Judge D. A. Christian and Col. R. B. Poore were nominated and unani mously elected. For the appointments of delegates from the different County districts, the two jury rooms were occupied by Stonewall and Southside, and the court room by Clover Hill. The proceedings of these district meetings were about as follows Mr. M. J. Carson was elected Chairman of Southside and Mr. J. M. Miles, Secretary. The following three old incumbents of the County Execu tive Committee were reappointed Messrs. J. T. Moses, W. A. Moses, and R. W. Worley. The delegates tore present Appomattox at Buchan an were, Messrs. S. L. Ferguson, W. H. Lewis, R. W. Worley, and J. M. Miles. In the Clover Hill district meet ing Mr. J. K. Hannah was elected Chairman, and W. J. Trent Secre tary. The members appointed for the Executive Committee were Messrs. J. D. Watkins, R. A. OBryant. W. H. Ligon and W. D. Thornton. The Delegates to the convention were Messrs. W. J. Trent, M. E. Agee, J. W. Flood J. K. Hannah and J. W. Flood. The Chairman of Stonewall was Dr. A. A. Rice and Secretary, Jos eph Button. The following were the member of the Executive Com mittee appointed from Stonewall Messrs. Jos. Button, J.R. Horsley, S.P.Taylor,and Cary Carson.The del egates to the convention were Mesers. J. R. Horsley S. C. Stratton, Jos. Button,and E. L. Anderson. The entire meeting passed off with out a hitch, a harmonious concensus of opiuion prevailing throughout. In all the motions and nominations made and carried not a dissenting voice was heard, showing that the candidate from Appomattox is heartily backed by his county. The delegates, fifteen in number, were instructed to vote for Hon. H. D. Flood, from start to finish.

document.text: At a largely attended meeting ot the Committee, on Farmers Institute held at this office last Saturday the committee decided to postpone the Institute until Friday and Saturday, August 20 and 21. This action of the committee was taken mainly with the view of changing the dates from a busy Beason with our farmers so that all the agriculturalists of the county might be in attendance. Also to avoid the dates of the Baptist Associations which would have con flicted with the former dates. The committee urged the importance of a meeting here next court, Aug. 5tb of all the farmers from each pre cinct in the county, for the purpose of ascertaining the amount of pro visions each precinct in the county will furnish. The general commit tee was increased, which now stands as follows Committee on Dinner  W. H Ligon, T. A. Smith, Joel Cawthorn D. Mott Robertson J. F. Purdum, H C. Babcock, S. C. Stratton, James D. Martin, J. K. Hannah and Maj. J. W. Flood. Committee called to meet court day. Committee ou ArrangementsT. A. Caldwell, W. J. Trent and J. H. Robertson. Meet court day. Committee on PublicationL. E. Smith and A. H. Clement Meet court day. Committee ou MusicC. A. Ab bitt, Clinton Cawthorn, C. W. Han cock, J. R. Caldwell and Peter Strat ton. Meet court day. Other members ave J. R. Hors ley, Dr. T. W. Evans and Judge D A. Christian. Every Appomattox farmer is in vited to attend these committee meetings, especially the precinct meetings which will be held here on next court. _ __________

document.text: Appomattox High School. The following medals are offered to students attending tiie High SchoolA.  B. T im e r Metis! Scholarship, A. H. Clement. Essay Medal, by Rev. Dr. Geo. Braxton Taylor. Mathematics, by Snpt. J, K . Hannah. Penmin hip, bv P. R. Wooldridge. Elocution, by Princi pal J . G.  Fisher. Others will be announced as offered. Beginning the first of March Prof. Fisher will conduct a Special Normal Course adapted to the needs of students and teachers preparing for. the State Examination. This course will embrace all the subjects taught iu the public schools, aud also book-keeping if te students de sire it. J . G. F isb e k , Principal. Death of JTrs. Jenkins. Departed this life on the 15tli inst. Mrs. Eunice Shields Jeukins, the wife of our well known aud highly esteemed couutymau Mr. Joel W. .Jenkins, in the 30th year of her age. Mrs. Jenkins had been a great sufferer tor-many months and had several of the most skillful physicians to atteud her, but all in vain. Her work here was finished and the great Omnipotent took her home. Her life has been that of a Christian soldier, haviug entered the Lorus service in her early girlhood as a member of St. Pauls Episcopal church in this county, but later in life, under honest convictions she united with New Hope Baptist church, iu which she proved a faith ful, active worker, even after dis ease had fastened itself upon her. Mrs. Jenkins is survived by her aged paieuts, three brothers aud one sister, a devoted husband aud an only child, who with many other elatives and a host of friends mourn her death.  Blessed are the dead which die iu the Lord. Mrs. Jen kiiis was the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. J . J . Cheadle of this county. Truly the sympathetic hearts of our people go out to all the bereaved ouesa loving daugh ter, a foud sister and a faithful wife has been taken. In the pres ence of a large number of relatives and friends, the funeral services were conducted by her pastor Rev. P. T. Warren aud she was laid to rest in the family cemetery Satur day. Asleep in Jesus! O. how sweet To be lor such a slumber meeV With holy confidence to sing That death has lost its venomed sting. Ji.

document.text: The many friends in this county of Mrs. Mary E. Hannah were greived to learn of her death, which occurred at the residence of her son- in-law, Mr. J. L. Lewis, in Lynch burg last Sunday. The deceased was 73 years old and was a consist ent Christian and member of the Prestiyterian church at the time of her death. Her remains were in terred at her late residence near Pamplin City Tuesday. Mrs. Han nah was the widow of the late Wm. Hannah, who was a gallant Confed erate soldier and who represented this district in the State Senate for a number of years. They are sur vived by four sons and one daughter viz  Messrs. J. K., P. M. and Wal ter, of this county, and Wm. Han nah, of Norfolk, and Mrs. J. L- Lewis, of Lynchburg. These have a legacy left them worthy of emula tion iu the exemplary character of  the deceased.
